newsitem.title: NEW ZEALAND: Kiwifruit NZ to appeal court decision on sourcing.
newsitem.headline: Kiwifruit NZ to appeal court decision on sourcing.

text.p: Kiwifruit New Zealand said on Thursday it would appeal a High Court decision preventing it from marketing overseas-harvested fruit in foreign markets.
Kiwifruit NZ is the operating name of the Kiwifruit Marketing Board (NZKMB).
The case was brought to the High Court in Auckland by a group of concerned kiwifruit growers.
The court was asked to determine whether the NZKMB had the power to market -- outside New Zealand and Australia -- fruit other than that grown in New Zealand. It ruled it could not.
Kiwifruit NZ chairman John Palmer in a statement the appeal would be based on legal concerns rather than the specific outcome of the decision.
"Our legal advice is that the decision gives a narrow interpretation of our powers, which could potentially restrict the sensible operation of our business," he said.
Meanwhile the board has pledged to the court that it has no plans to buy overseas kiwifruit for resale overseas and would not do so without consulting growers.
Kiwifruit NZ communications manager Susan Robinson-Derus said the NZKMB was not even at the stage of determining which countries it might want to buy fruit from.
"This isn't something we're doing now, or contemplating doing in the next year or so. It is literally a concept that we want to be able to investigate."

Robinson-Derus said KNZ's present infrastructure earned revenue for only seven months of the year. The NZKMB wanted to explore the strategy of buying overseas kiwifruit as a means of enhancing grower returns and creating long-term value.
